div.p: I have been wanting to write so long, so long; and this letter, which shame at your writing first has makes me begin at an odd moment, will presumably be in and out of its envelope many times before it gets finished. Shame, because it is I who should have acknowledged your two books, not you my article. I found the Comet on my return, and have recently only finished it; the American book - I have not even begun! My brother has been at the point of death; he seems, after nearly a month’s anxiety, out of momentary danger, but paralysed of one side + miserably weak, like an old, old man. I am able to do nothing practical (he has a firstrate wife) but the constant running to + fro, + the unavowed anxiety seem to have cut into all my spare time - And somehow I never have spare time, because I am a bad worker; + worst of all a very, very phenomenally slow reader. And I cannot mix books any more than other folk can mix wines: I must finish what I am reading + then ponderously set to something else - (damn: the dinnerbell, always a meal: NB no meals or mealtimes after the Comet)

I foresee I shall begin your American book the day after tomorrow; meanwhile, by way of thanks for it, I am sending you the most delightful thing I can imagine, a letter not in the least intended for you - indeed I had a free fight to wrest this very shy old friend’s permission to send it. She is - well, judge whether she isn’t exactly the reader one would pray for. Besides this, she is a Cambridge woman, knows economics very well; + has seen America from the inside, i.e. all manner of unlikely places. I can imagine nothing so pleasing as such pleasure as this letter means. I also venture to send you + your dear wife a facsimile of a drawing by Sargent which, though done sixteen or seventeen years ago, is still rather like me.

Well - I shall write to you about the American book, but now, a few words about the Comet. (No, not a word more today, for I have a friend with me who is already constitutionally unpunctual, a “poetic” person +, having been meant myself for a Samurai, I do not like keeping my dinner waiting - so, more anon, dear friends) -

Next evening How much of what I want to say shall I have time to put down (it is cold as it can be only in the South, with the wind smiting like a hand full of ice snow off the blue + white mountains, + the stone pine groaning + the olive wood sputtering + smelling delicious) Well! About the Comet . The novel part of it seems to me very fine in quality. (And, is it rude to say so? far finer as a [?] literary expression than any of your previous books) - the quality of Mr Lewisham, a sort of contained, overallish passionateness which, just because it is of the whole bodily life , heart lungs + muscle, is always human, never - well, animal. Do you understand? Of course, for you have done this feat yourself. And all the tragedy of the poor odious foolish boy is direct + as the Germans say “packs one” - Moreover, the criticism of the present state of things is just + scathing - I think this sort of holding the mirror up to the tolerated unnecessary follies of our days (the splendid passage on the Boer + German wars, + many others) is one of the most useful things a writer can do.

It is the mission of the prophet to use the future (of course no real future ever) to preach at the present from; + what we want most is the habit of considering the present as a [line missing, see original] its most successful details as mere momentary stop gaps: the past, with all its great gifts, has left us a Pandora’s nuisance in the shape of acquiescence + the belief that what has been must be, whereas nine times out of ten t’is the other way on.

So, I like the first part of the Comet extremely. Of course you yourself must feel what everyone tells me, that the 2d part is a falling off. The actual meteorological business is really tremendously fine (the comet + its vapours with the naval battle) - But then one comes to understand + to care. This is probably inevitable. Once You yourself cannot know what kind of change the green vapours have wrought. Have vicious possibilities vanished? fools become wise, etc? etc. Tis an inconceivable thing; but quite worth filling in for the sake of the frame work it affords you. Here again, the useful + (to me, but not many others) interesting work of suggesting change. The mischief is that you cannot really tell us enough of that change. Your logical premise is false: i.e. people become sensible + good while surrounded by the things of folly + selfishness. There are some things which have provoked discussion in my + I suppose many other circles. Are you throwing dust in our eyes for fear of the [?] young person’s parents, or do y are you at a loss how the question of sexual love etc. will evolve after the green vapours? Do you

Like the woman in Dumas’ play “Vous pouvez me le dire puisque je suis une femme d’esprit” - i.e. that is, if you have anything to say, + do not merely drop the “cloud” - over the future of love as Ruskin did over the past of glaciers. I can imagine two readings of the suggestion your postscript contains. 1o When people shall have become morally better; a great many arrangements, including ménage à quatre , free love etc. etc., which would entail monstrous disorder nowadays if avowedly tolerated, would become purely personal questions, offspring + inheritance etc being settled for, and wholesomeness of individuals looking after the business. 2do When people shall have come to live mere natural lives, certain possibilities, certain deviations + scissions of feeling which our imperfection excludes as morbid, [unwholesome] etc. will become possible; and among these [?] of the emotional possibilities, platonic love as a reality; even as un-sexual love between near blood relations has become possible in consequence of the suppression of incest - Now, which, or any of these? You are English, + perhaps my Latin decency or indecency astonishes + abashes you. Anyhow, I feel that you, like me, believe that there may be surprises in store for the future: the surprise of much becoming permissible; only the “green vapours” will not come unless these future permissible things are meanwhile forbidden - (But not I don’t choose to be forbidden these plain questions) -

Dear Mr Wells - This letter is already too long by half, + it is not half finished, so I send it off. And add that since two days I have been reading your entrancing America. You have never done anything so good. I am only at the 3d chapter, + if I have time to write, + you to read, I will write again when I have finished it. I feel as if it had been written expressly for me , + this is probably the feeling of each of your intelligent + willing readers. All my friend writer is absolutely what I think. Give my love - give this letter - to your dear wife. I am always so grateful for your quick, light cordiality towards a rather disputative stranger. When you have time let me know about the Fabians, whether I can join.
